Award.AwardTitle: Prenatal Origins of Infant Social Responsiveness

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project, Dr. Lickliter will examine whether and to what extent prenatal sensory experience contributes to the emergence and development of postnatal social responsiveness. Although social responsiveness is a fundamental characteristic of human infant behavior and supports emotional, cognitive, and language development, little is currently known about the possible roles of prenatal sensory experience in neonatal social behavior. As a result of this gap in our knowledge, some developmental scientists have suggested that infant social responsiveness is innate, independent of prior experience. Our lack of knowledge in this area is due in part to the very restricted prenatal manipulations possible with human fetuses. Working with an animal model, the bobwhite quail, Dr. Lickliter and his research team have previously shown that prenatal sensory experience plays a key role in establishing postnatal perceptual preferences in the neonate. This research project will extend this work to determine what types of prenatal experiences facilitate the emergence of early social skills, including social orienting, social contingency detection and learning, and the ability for individual recognition of social partners. By comparing quail chicks who received modified prenatal sensory experience with chicks who received typical patterns of prenatal sensory experience, this project will uncover what types and amounts of prenatal experience promote or interfere with the development of neonatal social responsiveness. The findings of this project will provide a foundation for understanding the relationship between prenatal experience and postnatal behavior and will inform research directions for human-based studies of early perceptual, cognitive, and social development.

The results of this work will allow better integration of the prenatal period into current theories of both typical and atypical behavioral development. For example, the findings obtained can inform the care and management of preterm infants, who make up 12% of births in the US and are at risk for atypical perceptual, cognitive, and social outcomes as a result of being deprived of normal patterns of prenatal sensory experience. The project will also provide multiple training opportunities for graduate and undergraduate students from ethnically diverse backgrounds. The results of this work will be broadly disseminated in presentations at conferences, colloquia, journal publications, and book chapters.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The prenatal environment provides the embryo or fetus a variety of concurrent tactile, vestibular, chemical, and auditory experience. Whether and to what extent this prenatal sensory experience facilitates infants' development of individual recognition, social learning, and social motivation following birth has received little if any research attention. We have found that the use of an animal model offers an essential step in advancing our knowledge of the possible mechanisms of early social development. Studies that manipulate human fetuses and infants are necessarily severly limited and the use of animal models allows the collection of data under more controlled conditions that would be allowed with human fetuses and infants and is a key strategy for connecting theories of early social development with biological and neurophysiological mechanisms.

This project provided evidence of the importance of prenatal sensory experience to infant social development.  In particular, using an animal model, the project demonstrated that specific features of prenatal sensory experience, particularly the availability of intersensory redundancy (the same information temporally synchronized across two or more senses) can play a key role in the emergence of early postnatal social responsiveness.  Social events provide young infants exaggerated amounts of intersensory redundancy relative to non-social events (for example, synchronized faces and voices) and we found that prenatal sensitivity to and experience with redundancy across the senses prior to birth contributes to infants' initial preferential attention to or bias for social stimulation. Specific outcomes of the project included the discovery that exposure to prenatal intersensory redundancy (1) supports the development of infants' social contingency detection and learning and (2) contributes to perceptual narrowing for species-typical maternal vocalizations during early development.  We also found that embryos exposed to acoustically modified maternal vocalizations can generalize this prenatal familiarization and show modified postnatal auditory preferences for maternal vocalizations. 

The project provided multiple training opportunities for graduate and undergraduate students, the majority of which were underrepresented minorities, and our results were widely disseminated to both the scientific community and our local community in south Florida. Overall, the findings of the project will allow for better integration of the prenatal period of development into current theories of infant perceptual, cognitive, and social development.
